clinical_study.brief_title: Infection Control for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2
clinical_study.official_title: Expert Statements on Infection Control in Intensive Care Unit for Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome Coronavirus 2

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators aim to develop expert consensus statements on infection control management of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) in intensive care units (ICU).

detailed_description.textblock:
The pandemic of SARS-CoV-2 has grown exponentially in last few months with numerous patients requiring respiratory support and ICU admissions. The rapidly increasing number of infectious patients in ICU requires robust infection control management in order to prevent cross-transmission of virus to other patients or healthcare workers (HCWs). The understanding on epidemiology characteristics of SARS-CoV-2 and pathophysiology of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is still evolving and evidence on transmission of SARS-COV-2 in controlled healthcare-setting is either absent or conflicting. The main mode of transmission for SARS-CoV-2 is through droplets or fomite. The respiratory support interventions for these patients in ICU like non-invasive ventilation, high flow nasal oxygen, or tracheal intubation are aerosol generating procedures and may lead to airborne transmission of SARS-CoV-2. The viral shedding from serious and critical patients of COVID-19 is also known to be longer than mild and moderate illness. In absence of robust evidence, there is either conflicting or no recommendations available from international regulatory agencies on infection control management of SARS-CoV-2.
The investigators are going to use a modified Delphi based methodology involving global participating experts on infectious disease, intensive care and infection control. The objective is to achieve consensus statements on the infection control management of SARS-CoV-2 in ICU.
The whole process of this study will be done in the form of three-four rounds of Google Forms-based Delphi surveys. The survey questionnaire, will be prepared by the investigators after systematic search of available literature and concern areas in the infection control of SARS-CoV-2 in ICU. The survey questionnaire will be divided into five sections: 1. Design and engineering 2. Health-care workers 3. Personal protective equipment 4. Aerosol generating procedures 5. Disinfection and sterilisation. The majority of these questionnaire statements are to be rated on Likert scale and others have multiple choices. The participating experts comments and feedback will be collected through comment section after each question in round one. All the subsequent surveys will be iterative and the experts can give their opinion in each round using either open text or directly to steering group of investigators.

primary_outcome.description: Survey questionnaire with seven point Likert scale (1-3 means disagreement and 5-7 means agreement) and multiple choice statements

study_pop.textblock: 60-70 global experts in Infection Control, Infectious disease with experience of managing patients in ICUs will be invited to participate in study through e-mail with final expected participation of 35-40 experts.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria for participants
All the three should be there:
1. One or more publication on Infection Control or infectious disease in ICU in indexed journal.
2. Actively involved in management of COVID-19 patients.
3. H index (sourced from Scopus) above 10.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Those who do not accept the invitation or not meeting any of the inclusion criteria.
